p: Previous studies reported by Munhuweyi et al. [ 91] identified Botrytis cinerea and Penicillium spp. as some of the major decay causing pathogens in pomegranate fruit. These microbes were isolated from diseased pomegranate fruit during cold storage (5 ± 1 °C, 95 ± 2% RH). Pathogenicity and virulence of isolated microorganism were investigated and confirmed according to the Koch’s postulates [ 57, 91]. Fungal pathogens were grown in Potato Dextrose Agar (PDA) (Biolab, Modderfontein, South Africa) incubated at 25 °C for 8 to 14 days to obtain actively growing spores [ 91]. A solution of distilled water amended with Tween 20 (Sigma-Aldrich, St. Louis, MO, USA) at a concentration of 0.01 mL·L −1 was added to the PDA plates of each fungal colony. Finally, the resultant spores were counted using haemocytometer (Neubauer, Marienfeld-Superior, Lauda-Konigshofen, Germany) and optical microscope (Leica Wild M8 Transmitted Light Stereo Microscope, Wild Heerbrugg, Switzerland) and adjusted to a concentration of 1 × 10 9 spores L −1.
